item.title: Ingeborg Holm
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★

“Ingeborg Holm” is a Swedish social drama based on a play by Nils Krok, hailing from the early days of cinema and the alien planet of silent film.

item.title: Deux Jours, Une Nuit
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★

“Deux Jours, Une Nuit” (Two Days, One Night) reminds us of the people that are negatively affected by the growing wealth gap and the deteriorating middle class. The Dardenne brothers offer yet another important view into the world of the struggling, everyday Belgian worker.

The main character, Sandra (Marion Cotillard), is a young Belgian mother who is recovering from clinical depression. However, she returns from her sick leave to find that her boss has given her 16 coworkers a choice: receive 1000 euro bonuses or let Sandra return and keep her job. Sandra’s coworkers have already voted in favor of receiving bonuses, but the boss agrees to give her job back if Sandra can get a majority to change their mind by Monday, leaving her with just one weekend to track down her colleagues and ask them to change their votes.

item.title: Moonrise Kingdom
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★

I feel and see the nostalgia of summer’s end, first love, and youth itself in “Moonrise Kingdom”. Crisp visuals and endearing performances drive this film, and while the ending might be a bit harried, I still smile at the thought of this wonderful little fictional island. It’s easy to let yourself become spellbound by the mini-universes that Wes Anderson creates in his films, and this one is no different.

item.title: The Revenant
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★

While it’s not a film I particularly love, I admire “The Revenant” for its beauty, cinematography, and visceral depiction of the wild. This is a film that is meant to be seen on the big screen.

item.title: Carol
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

I am not by any means an expert on the subject of love, but I believe “Carol” is one of the most realistic and intelligent portrayals of love that I’ve seen in film.

item.title: The Hateful Eight
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★

Quentin Tarantino’s eighth film, “The Hateful Eight”, is some sort of twisted game of Clue in the style of a Western, set ten or so years after the American Civil War. Add a stellar cast and a beautiful original score written by Ennio Morricone and we’ve got ourselves a good movie that’s entertaining as hell.

item.title: Joy
item.description:
★ ★ ★

As the film celebrates strong matriarchal characters and the power of determination, I can’t help but wish “Joy” was better. This is David O. Russell’s third film in a row featuring the talented Jennifer Lawrence, but unlike “Silver Lining’s Playbook” and “American Hustle”, “Joy” is a bumpy ride that isn’t always enjoyable.

item.title: The Force Awakens
item.description:
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

The most anticipated movie of the year, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens", lives up to all the hype, and J. J. Abrams delivers the best early Christmas present I could ask for.

item.title: Guide to My Film Review Style
item.description: In the future, I'll be posting reviews of films I watch so I can keep a film journal of sorts.

item.title: First Post - Goals
item.description: With fall quarter officially over, I finally found the time to get this site up and make it look decent (I hope). For my first post, I just wanted to type out what I hope this website/blog can be:
